sentence: A staggering 21.5 million Americans were exposed in a government data breach revealed yesterday.

A new cybersecurity ETF aims to take on hackers -- as well as an existing peer that has gained assets at a blistering pace.First Trust Nasdaq CEA Cybersecurity ( CIBR ) debuted July 7 and is a lower-cost rival to one of this year's hottest exchange traded funds.
"We look at cybersecurity as one of those themes in the early stages of a long-term secular growth trend," says Ryan Issakainen, exchange traded fund strategist at First Trust Advisors.
What Issakainen means is that successful investors have been tapping into cybersecurity stocks.
The industry is growing in importance as the world becomes more interconnected and businesses move to the cloud.
Recent and highly publicized data breaches atPremera Blue Cross ,Anthem ( ANTM ),Sony ( SNE ) andHome Depot ( HD ) show that both corporations and government entities are vulnerable to hack attacks.
The new ETF holds technology and industrial companies engaged in thwarting these attacks.
They build, implement and manage the security protocols that safeguard private and public networks, computers and mobile devices.
The slew of data breaches in the past year helpedPureFunds ISE Cybersecurity ( HACK ) cross a billion dollars in assets in less than eight months after its November 2014 debut.
Despite HACK's first-mover advantage, Issakainen believes his cybersecurity ETF offers several key advantages.
First, the underlying index is liquidity weighted.
So less liquid holdings get a smaller stake of assets.
"The liquidity of underlying shares is important to keep in mind as investors want to trade in and out of the fund," Issakainen said.
"If sentiment turns against one of those companies and it makes up a large portion of an ETF, there's potential risk if sellers enter the market all at one time."
It's an especially important consideration in a niche industry with many relatively young firms in a period of fast and furious growth.
CIBR's liquidity-weighted structure allows it "to grow or contract with as little market impact as possible," Issakainen explained.
One of its lowest ranked holdings isIntralinks (IL), with 0.52% portfolio weighting.
By comparison, Intralinks is the No.
1 holding in HACK, with 4.4% portfolio weighting.
Intralinks has a market capitalization of $657 million.
The stock's average daily volume is about 360,000 shares.
Another key difference between the two ETFs is cost.
CIBR has a 0.60% expense ratio, or $60 in fees for every $10,000 invested.
HACK has a 0.75% expense ratio.
CIBR holds 34 stocks vs. 32 for HACK.
There's considerable holdings overlap, but weightings differ.
CIBR top five holdings areQihoo 360 (QIHU),FireEye (FEYE),Palo Alto Networks (PANW),Cisco (CSCO) andNXP Semiconductors (NXPI), with 5% or more of assets each.
HACK rose 0.5% on the stock market today .
It's 8% off its June 22 high of 33.91.
